unnormalised: Someone asked me what’s the deal with all these crazy discounts online, especially during sales like Flipkart’s Big Billion Days. Honestly, it's a mix of things, bhai.
normalised: Someone asked me what's the deal with all these crazy discounts online, especially during sales like Flipkart's Big Billion Days. Honestly, it's a mix of things, brother.

unnormalised: First off, a lot of it is just good ol’ marketing. They inflate the MRP (Maximum Retail Price) by, say, 20%, then offer a “massive” 50% discount to make it look super attractive. So, you're not really saving 50% off the actual price it should be. They rely on people not doing their research and just jumping on the "deal".
normalised: First off, a lot of it is just good old marketing. They inflate the M-R-P (Maximum Retail Price) by, say, twenty percent, then offer a "massive" fifty percent discount to make it look super attractive. So, you're not really saving fifty percent off the actual price it should be. They rely on people not doing their research and just jumping on the "deal".

unnormalised: Then there's the thing about older stock. Companies need to clear out last season's phones, models, or whatever. You might be getting a phone with 4GB RAM that was released a year ago at a steal price of Rs. 8,000, but there are way better options if you look around.
normalised: Then there's the thing about older stock. Companies need to clear out last season's phones, models, or whatever. You might be getting a phone with four gigabyte R-A-M that was released a year ago at a steal price of rupee eight thousand, but there are way better options if you look around.

unnormalised: Sometimes, the discounts are legit for specific brands to increase their sales volume. Think something like a limited-time discount of Rs. 1500 off on a certain type of headphones or 10% cashback on using a specific credit card like SBI. They're willing to take a hit to grab more market share.
normalised: Sometimes, the discounts are legitimate for specific brands to increase their sales volume. Think something like a limited-time discount of rupee one thousand five hundred off on a certain type of headphones or ten percent cashback on using a specific credit card like S-B-I. They're willing to take a hit to grab more market share.

unnormalised: And finally, watch out for fake reviews and dodgy sellers! I once bought a "genuine" leather wallet for Rs. 499, only to find it was plastic. Always check seller ratings and product reviews before clicking "buy now," especially on items with huge discounts. Basically, shop smart, compare prices, and don’t just get swayed by big numbers!
